The groundwater argument is wrong: gas drilling and fracking occur far deeper than any groundwater, and is contained in steel pipes to contain the fracking pressure and prevent gas (and fluid) escape. Once drilling and fracking is completed, the gas pads are quite unobtrusive, and much more widely spaced than conventional drilling - fracking is environmentally more benign than any other method.

original:
No, I am really not. Philosophy - from the Greek "philos' meaning love and "sophos" meaning "Wisdom", the love of wisdom - is literally the study of how to think straight.

If you haven't learned philosophy, you will never be able to form a logical thought. No, what people think they are doing isn't logic. Logic is a set of rules. To think logically you have to know those rules, and apply those rules (much like algebra is a set of rules you have to know and apply to get the right answer).

To think you can be logical without studying philosophy is like claiming you can do algebra without learning to count first. 

Here's how it works:
Philosophers figure out how to understand things.
Scientists use those techniques to understand a particular thing.
Engineers use that understanding to solve practical problems.

Unfortunately - because true logic is so often counter-intuitive, those not schooled in it tend to think actual logical arguments are "stupid" because their intuition says so.

original:
What a bunch of IDIOTS. The most fair and COLLECTIBLE tax is a SALES TAX. 
The success of a tax is if it is widespread, can be enforced easily and is paid by those who actually purchase goods and services. 
The fewer collectors of a tax the better, and there are much fewer businesses to collect a sales tax than there are residents, who may or may not honestly pay an income tax There are a LOT of income tax cheaters and to enforce collection of income tax requires a new State agency. 
Auditing businesses who collect sales tax is very straightforward and very few businesses of any size cheat on sales taxes. 
As a person increases their income, they buy more expensive items, therefore they pay more sales tax, Most states eliminate groceries from sales tax, so as to not unfairly hit the poor, so the sales tax is on items people CHOOSE to buy. original:
That narrative is, of course, a lie. Russia gave nothing to the Clinton foundation. Other agencies, with SecState approval, acquired, not uranium, but mineral rights to a yellowcake deposit, which was subsequently sold a couple of times until it fell into a 46% ownership by a Russian corp.

The US has for years sold yellowcake to Russia, and we have for decades bought yellowcake from Russia. Yellowcake is a restricted export, and if the state dept chooses, none will go to Russia. They can't just ship it out without a permit.

So this particular "scandal" really is nothing, except to idiots too lazy to look into it. Even then, the whole thing is a phony scandal. Only fools repeat it, or those slimy liars who consider their fellow citizens to be fools. 

Bad show, Motley.

original:
My first impression of Fairbanks in May of 1990 was "What a dump. I bet I end up living here." I ended up living here. It is decidedly not a dump.

After several years in Denali (where I met my now wife) we settled in Fairbanks for better job prospects. Initially I wasn't sure about the place but as I came to learn the extensive trail system the mountain biker in me went nuts. I also found plenty of things to get involved in because Fairbanks residents have to create their own good times. People here are doers. When you meet someone questions don't revolve around jobs, we ask where have you hiked/biked/hunted/fished/climbed/etc. In other words, how have you taken advantage of this place and what it offers? You can go to a party and find a millionaire swapping trail tales with a plumber and they've known each other for years and you can't tell which is which from the looks of them.

As for suggestions, visit in March. There is no finer place on Earth than Fairbanks, Alaska, in March.
censored:

Initially I wasn't sure about the place but as I came to learn the extensive trail system the mountain biker in me went nuts. I also found plenty of things to get involved in because Fairbanks residents have to create their own good times. People here are doers. When you meet someone questions don't revolve around jobs, we ask where have you hiked/biked/hunted/fished/climbed/etc. In other words, how have you taken advantage of this place and what it offers? You can go to a party and find a millionaire swapping trail tales with a plumber and they've known each other for years and you can't tell which is which from the looks of them.

As for suggestions, visit in March. There is no finer place on Earth than Fairbanks, Alaska, in March.

original:
How many times have you seen the following:  One transport pulling out to pass another and taking the next 10 minutes and miles of highway to finally get past.   All this and 1/2 hour later the truck which passed is 15 - 30 seconds ahead of the slower truck.    It's just not worth it.

Trucks should be in a restricted lane, and passing should be prohibited, except in designated areas.

Concurrent with this should be driver education about lane discipline and yielding (instead of blocking) when a car comes up from behind.    It is not up to drivers to enforce the speed limit.    So if a car is tailgating - just move over and let him/her pass.    Don't be a stubborn jerk and block traffic, which should be ticketable offence.     That will help traffic flow, and if the tailgater is really speeding (or weaving in and out) leave it up to the police to catch them.

It is just silly to argue that Vancouver is somehow facing the problems of a high density city, given the news headlines in Vancouver, this year, in 2017:

"Vancouver has the highest proportion of empty, underused homes in 35 years"
"Number of empty homes in Vancouver hits record high"
"Data shows 98% increase in empty homes since 2001"
"New census counts 25,502 unoccupied homes in Vancouver, for 15 per cent jump over 2011"

And do you know what, editors?

This silliness in your newspaper today is what you get when you avoid the elephant in the room, which is the impact of the billions and billions of dollars of overseas money flooding in.

See, if instead you started your editorial decision-making with that key, central mechanism front and center, you would not be left with egg on your face for publishing silliness such as Vancouver facing a high-density problem (roll eyes).

Vancouver faces an overseas-billions-flooding-in problem. All else is secondary to it.

original:
What a load of cods-wallop.  Those in the temperance movement, and make no mistake, that's exactly what MADD is - a temperance movement,  are fond of using scientifically unsound catch-phrases such as "Impairment Starts With The First Drink."  The author of this piece is cut from the same cloth.  

Unless we have 0.00 as the only acceptable Blood Alcohol Content, then we must by definition, establish a BAC level beyond which one is considered impaired.  Which means in the converse, below that limit, one is not considered impaired.  It must be set at some level.  

There is no basis upon which to justify a change to 0.05 from 0.08 as being that ideal limit.  This is completely a political decision, not borne of research, science or evidence.  

Wasn't it Trudeau who pledged "evidence-based" decision making in his government?  What a hypocrite!

Before you go on a "you're a stupid liberal" rant I'll let you know that I'm for border security. But I think we need better solutions than hard-line deportation. Experience shows it actually makes the issues that do exist worse (look at Alabama or Arizona). We need a combination of better border security and a way to solve the issue of the 11 million already here. This was pretty much what Obama was trying to do, but "build a wall" is a better metaphor for the cherry-picking uniformed people in society I guess.

original:
Wonderful skewering of the aspiring "Fat-Shamer in Chief" by Tiothy Egan in today's NY Times:

"So, in the spirit of the discourse that Trump has brought us to, let’s objectify the Republican nominee on his terms. This guy is fat. Bigly. He’s got an extra chin, a gut you wouldn’t want to see riding above a bathing suit, and a rear that serves no purpose but ballast.

At 6-foot-2, the height that he has long given profile writers, ... [b]y government guidelines, Trump is obese. In a weasel move to avoid that classification, Trump now says he is 6-foot-3, which makes him merely overweight. How he grew an inch, at the age of 70, is a story that has escaped his hagiographers at Fox.

Trump’s ducktail hairdo, colored in a hue unknown to nature, is a complicated comb-over inspired by Dr. Seuss.

Trump’s hands are smaller than 85 percent of American men. No surprise he lies about that.

'Fat, drunk and stupid is no way to go through life' (from Animal House) .. Trump .. has two of the three."

As some have posted, probably scud-running under VFR. With the near- total destruction of the aircraft, we'll probably never definitively know exactly what went wrong. But the ADS-B data should show their altitude and track, and we'll know if they filed IFR or not. If they were on an IFR plan, they were way off in altitude, which usually requires at least a 2000' clearance from the highest terrain in the vicinity. If they had an emergency at altitude, they should have had time to at least issue a mayday. But from the photo and reports from the site, it looks as though they flew straight into the mountain at cruise speed.

I had enough experiences with Hageland - many of which a non-pilot would not have been aware - that I really, really tried to avoid them. That said, all the air taxis have their cowboys. I watched one taking off recently, in clear weather, yanking the plane into a 30-degree or greater bank, 100' above the ground. Engine failure and a plane full of dead souls. Stupid.

1. You're an idiot. I said nothing about medical care, and I wasn't talking about hunter/gatherers. It is a FACT that the first plastered walls were built by the SAME early farmers who also built the first grain stores. Agriculture allowed, for the first time, overproduction of food - so working for a few months a year would provide food for the rest of the year. Plaster was a major thing - it has ZERO survival value. It takes days of backbreaking labour, maintaining a fire at very high heat constantly - for no reward other than aesthetics. It's something that would never have happened in a society without an abundance of leisure time. And it's important that it did - the same fire-handling techniques they developed to make their walls smooth - was what allowed their grandchildren to smelt ore and end the stone age.

On the other side of the coin:

"A judge has reopened a major legal controversy by ruling that accused people can claim they were too drunk to be found culpable of committing crimes.
Presiding over a sexual assault case in Southwestern Ontario, Mr. Justice Terrence Patterson of the Superior Court of Ontario ruled that Parliament violated the Charter of Rights with a 1995 law that prohibits the so-called defence of excessive intoxication.
The ruling opened the door for Carl Frederick Fleming, 62, to argue that he was too drunk to appreciate his actions when he sexually assaulted a St. Thomas, Ont., woman in 2009."

original: Anchor Rides requires a 48-72 hour appointment for every ride.  You can't just call them the day of your appointment.  Also, if you're tied up at a doctor's office at the  time you've scheduled them to pick you up, they don't come back!  They will also tell you they can't get you to your appointment at the time you require.  Instead you can go 2 hours earlier or an hour later.Finances are another consideration.  It costs $3.50 for a one-way ride on Anchor Rides.  As to exercise, and lifestyles, most of us seniors can't afford a cheeseburger or cable TV, and I get a minimum of 1 mile a day of walking in just going to the bus stop. Enjoy your health while you have it.  I worked for 40 years to make a world as good as I could for your generation only to have my pension stolen by some idiot who's living somewhere there's no extradition.  I'd like  to see you try to live on $975 a month social security.  Quit judging others.

original:
The legislature has passed stringent laws that make it a crime for any corporation's board members to vote if they have a conflict of interest.  That means everyone from Exxon and city or borough Assemblies, right down to small charitable groups.   And the small boards that I'm on observe this rule carefully.

But this same legislature, in its wisdom, allows members to vote even if they have a gross conflict of interest!  That's how we got the current special deals for oil companies:  two legislators who are also executives of a big oil company cast the deciding votes.

We still need to rein in these "corrupt bastards."  (Not my insult-- some gave that name to themselves a few years ago.)

There are many parts of Canada - rural and urban  -where drivers do not believe pedestrians and bicyclists belong on or near the road with them.

I have witnessed cars attempting to force bikes off the road  and have seen  cars, buses, garbage trucks and delivery fans exceed the speed limit at school crossings and on roads where pedestrians must share the curb.

The killings will continue as long as drivers remain ignorant of their obligations and responsibilities.

There are parts of the world where drivers drive efficiently and safely, where they stop for pedestrians crossing the road because it is the right thing to do and always always always slow down when or near pedestrians and bicyclists.

Travel to these countries and see for yourself: Germany, Sweden, Norway and Finland to name a few.

It is no coincidence these countries also rank highest on human and social development  and quality of education.

Stupidity is no excuse for driving badly. Smugness  is no excuse for bullying.

original:
What utter garbage! The Globe's editors are showing disgusting authoritarian tendencies with this tripe.

Senators have been appointed to do a job. In order to do this job, they have been given certain powers in full accordance with the constitution of Canada.

If you don't like the manner in which they exercise their powers, that's one thing - just part of the normal grumbling about politics that comes hand-in-hand with any issue. And if you don't like the powers they have, a very simple procedure is open to you: amend the constitution.

original:
Listen ... I think that all or most of the actions of those who started this mess - from the original editorial writer who half-jokingly suggested an "Appropriation Prize," to the lunkheads (Ken Whyte chief among them) who started actually putting up time and money to start one - were reprehensible and naively tone-deaf.
Thanks to them, this whole thing turned into a contest to see who could out-idiot the other and it ended up with grown men crying over live microphones in CBC studios.
But ... can non-Indigenous people write about Indigenous issues? The answer is ... must always be ... a resounding yes.
That's because all writing, like any artform, is inherently organic. As humans, we write to inform, inspire or provoke. We do this by writing about what inform, inspires and provokes us. Writing should never be bounded by race or ideology or cultural "experiences."
This hubbub is going to have a chilling effect on the writing and coverage of indigenous subjects in Canada.
censored:
Listen ... I <CSD> that all or most of the actions of those who started this mess - from the original editorial writer who half-jokingly suggested an "Appropriation Prize," to the lunkheads (Ken Whyte chief among them) who started actually putting up time and money to start one - were reprehensible and naively tone-deaf.
Thanks to them, this whole thing turned into a contest to see who could out-<CSD> the other and it ended up with grown men crying over live microphones in CBC studios.
But ... can non-Indigenous people write about Indigenous issues? The answer is ... must always be ... a resounding yes.
That's because all writing, like any artform, is inherently organic. As humans, we write to inform, inspire or provoke. We do this by writing about what inform, inspires and provokes us. Writing should never be bounded by race or ideology or cultural "experiences."
This hubbub is going to have a chilling effect on the writing and coverage of indigenous subjects in Canada.
